summary_points.title: US Tariff Draft Notice Sparks Sell-Off
summary_points.summary: The United States’ draft notification of an additional 25% tariff on Indian imports triggered a broad-based sell-off in Indian equity markets on Tuesday. Benchmark indices Nifty50 and BSE Sensex plunged over 1% each—Nifty fell 255.70 points to 24,712.05 and Sensex dropped 849.37 points to 80,786.54—driven by heightened trade tension fears and a sudden surge in risk-off sentiment among investors.

summary_points.title: Global Market Slump Adds to Downside Pressure
summary_points.summary: Asian equities opened lower following Wall Street’s lead as U.S. tariff threats and disappointing macro data weighed on sentiment. Japan’s Nikkei fell over 1%, South Korea’s Kospi lost nearly 0.9%, and Hang Seng futures signaled further weakness. U.S. indices also ended in the red, with the Dow down 0.77% and S&P 500 off 0.43%, exacerbating bearish cues for Indian markets.

summary_points.title: Foreign Fund Outflows Intensify Market Weakness
summary_points.summary: Continuous foreign institutional investor (FII) withdrawals compounded market jitters, as overseas investors sold down Indian equities amid rising geopolitical risks and global monetary tightening. The sustained outflow trend dented liquidity and exerted downward pressure on the rupee, reinforcing a cautious stance among domestic participants.

summary_points.title: Technical Playbook: Paradeep Phosphates Recommendation
summary_points.summary: MarketSmith India has flagged Paradeep Phosphates for a potential rebound, highlighting a downward-sloping trendline breakout. With a current P/E of 39.31 and 52-week high at ₹3,743, analysts recommend buying in the ₹3,200–3,280 zone with a target of ₹3,800 over two to three months and a stop-loss at ₹3,050. Key risks include export trade hurdles, U.S. probe concerns, intense price competition, and inventory overhang.

summary_points.title: Expert Views: Risk-Off Momentum Dominates
summary_points.summary: Strategists such as Dr. V.K. Vijayakumar of Geojit Investments and Sudeep Shah of SBI Securities noted that the tariff shock triggered a broader risk-off wave across domestic markets. They pointed to currency swings, falling commodity prices, and technical breakdowns below key support levels as factors reinforcing investor caution and driving the sharp intraday corrections.

summary_points.title: Indian Markets Halted for Ganesh Chaturthi Holiday
summary_points.summary: While global markets were mixed, Indian exchanges remained closed today in observance of Ganesh Chaturthi. Despite the holiday pause, market participants monitored Asia’s steady performance and braced for reopening next week amid lingering concerns over trade tensions and policy developments.

articles.title: Indian stock market closed today for Ganesh Chaturthi - The Tribune
articles.snippet: Indian stock markets remained shut on Wednesday on account of Ganesh Chaturthi. Since the festival is a state holiday in Maharashtra, both the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) and the National Stock Exchange (NSE), which are headquartered in Mumbai, observed a trading holiday.

market_drivers.summary: Today’s market was weighed down by growing US tariff concerns and ongoing foreign institutional selling, which fueled profit booking across big‐cap names such as Sun Pharma, Adani Ports and Power Grid. While strong domestic liquidity and talk of GST and tax reforms offered some underpinning, easing corporate earnings momentum and sluggish consumer spending capped upside. Sectorally, metals, realty and pharma led declines, even as FMCG stocks held up relatively well. In sum, a mix of global tariff jitters, FII outflows, earnings uncertainty and targeted sector weakness dictated the trading session’s subdued performance.
